awd_abstract_narration:
Multiple astronomical observations have established that about 85% of the matter in the universe is not made of known particles. Deciphering the nature of this so-called Dark Matter is of fundamental importance to cosmology, astrophysics, and high-energy particle physics. A leading hypothesis is that it is comprised of Weakly Interacting Massive Particles, or WIMPs, that were produced moments after the Big Bang. If WIMPs are the dark matter, then their presence in our galaxy may be detectable via scattering from atomic nuclei in detectors located deep underground to help reject backgrounds due to cosmic rays.

The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) Collaboration has pioneered the use of low temperature phonon-mediated detectors to detect the rare scattering of WIMPs on nuclei and distinguish them from backgrounds. This work will have a broad impact which extends beyond a dark matter search. The technical developments will further advance phonon-mediated detectors, which have already found many applications in science and technology.

This award will provide support for the design and fabrication of a next-generation (G2) experiment, SuperCDMS SNOLAB, which will operate at the deepest large clean underground laboratory in the world. The high background rejection and control of contamination that the SuperCDMS technology offers provide significant advantages compared to other technologies. The baseline design for this new experiment will deploy an initial 50 kg payload of germanium (Ge) and silicon (Si) detectors. Some of these detectors will be operated in a manner that provides very low energy thresholds and thus world-leading sensitivity to the lowest dark matter particle masses (< 0.5 GeV) and multiple-target complementarity in a single experiment. It will provide a strong possibility of the discovery of particle dark matter and detailed information on its properties.

This award will also contribute to the training of undergraduate and graduate students and postdoctoral researchers, using techniques at the leading edge of measurement technologies. SuperCDMS scientists will continue their involvement in public outreach, collaboration with K-12 teachers, and support for Berkeley physics majors who are training to teach science and for promising high school students from underserved backgrounds.

por.por_cntn:
Weakly Interacting Massive Particles (WIMPs) are one of the main candidates to explain the mysterious dark matter in the universe, through new particle physics at the "TeV scale" or a "dark sector" which could co-exist with the ordinary matter that we know. A number of experiments are attempting to detect WIMPs from the halo of our galaxy through their scattering in sophisticated detectors located deep underground. Over the last 30 years, the National Science Foundation and the Department of Energy have supported several experiments to check this hypothesis. The Cryogenic Dark Matter Search (CDMS) series of experiments uses sophisticated low temperature detectors operating underground to detect interactions of these putative WIMPs and distinguish them from experimental background. This work is based on a combination of advanced photolithographic techniques, state-of-the-art superconducting and semi-conductor electronics, and low radioactivity techniques. Because of its energy sensitivity and excellent background rejection capability, the CDMS approach is well adapted to search for dark matter particles of low mass, which would deposit a very small amount of energy in their interactions with the nuclei or electrons of a target. And, it is complementary to the large liquid Xenon and Argon experiments, which explore the large WIMP masses.

After a very successful series of experiments based in the Soudan mine in Northern Minnesota, our collaboration proposed a new setup in the deeper SNOLAB underground laboratory in Sudbury (Ontario, Canada), with much improved radioactivity background and a more advanced set of detectors. The project was selected by the Department of Energy and the National Science Foundation as one of the Generation II searches for dark matter.

The construction funds provided by the two U.S. agencies and the Canada Fund for Innovation supported two goals:

  1. The fabrication of a new generation of very sensitive low temperature detectors, which, in the first two years after their installation, should allow us to explore the low mass region (1/2 to 10 times the mass of the proton) with world leading sensitivity;
  2. The construction of the advanced infrastructure needed for this payload: a large volume at very low temperature with very low vibration and radioactive background. The same infrastructure with minimal upgrades should allow us the deployment over the next decade of successive generations of detectors with increasing sensitivity and decreasing background levels, through the control of radioactivity and suppression of spurious energy deposition in our sensors.

Through this award, the NSF’s main responsibility was the fabrication and delivery of the detectors (Goal #1). The detectors are made of kilogram scale germanium and silicon single crystals with precisely patterned superconducting films on their faces to detect the phonons and ionization created by interactions. These detectors are then assembled into "towers", supporting them and providing electric and thermal connections. DOE was mostly responsible for the large cryostat, the shield, background control, and the overall infrastructure. DOE, NSF and Canada shared the responsibilities for the ultra-low noise electronics (with SQUIDs and HEMTs frontends), the data acquisition, the sophisticated event reconstruction software, and the analysis framework. This $40M class effort was managed as a single project and involved some 15 universities, three U.S. National Labs (SLAC, Fermilab and PNNL) and two Canadian Labs (TRIUMF and SNOLAB).

This construction project has successfully delivered the components promised to the agencies with the performance and within the budget agreed upon. Our team is transitioning to Installation, Integration and Operations, with support from the same agencies.


This project has been very well aligned with the NSF review criteria:

  • Intellectual merit: Providing an advanced infrastructure and a new generation of low temperature detectors for the search for dark matter in the universe will contribute by exploring one of the central issues in particle physics and cosmology. Although such a construction project does not, in itself, produce new scientific results, it is likely to enable important scientific discoveries.
  • Broader impacts on higher education: This project is also providing the infrastructure that will be used by several generations of undergraduates, graduate students and postdocs in their research. Through their involvement in the development of the detectors we are deploying now and of future technologies, we are providing them a unique training at the frontier of instrumentation and analysis in a multidisciplinary scientific environment. 
  • Broader impact on other fields: Moreover, the low temperature detector technologies developed by CDMS have consistently found applications in a broad range of fields (physics and astronomy, quantum information science, biology, health sciences, nonproliferation, etc.) and in return, CDMS is benefiting from the instrumentation advances in those fields.
  • Broader impact on science education:  Last but not least, the search for this mysterious dark matter in the universe captures the imagination of the public at large. SuperCDMS is using this interest to motivate K-12 students to consider a career in science and engineering, in particular students from underrepresented and underserved communities.
